    3.3 127

    Science and Modernism: A Panel

    The truth may not set us free, but it does make for lively arguments. The following three papers were given at the 1995 Modern Language Association panel, "Science and Modernism." Although the panelists did not consult each other in advance, the dialogue that emerges among these papers is remarkable. Both Christopher Herbert and George Levine bring Karl Pearson, the turn-of-the-century mathematician, eugenicist, and one of the "inventors" of modern statistics, into a controversy about the degree to which scientists taint their inquiry, and vice versa. Levine and Herbert both point out that Pearson's negotiation of indeterminancy and his mapping out of the constructedness of normativity presages the much later critiques of Michel Foucault and French post-structuralism; the implication is that we still have much to learn from historical inquiry into the intellectual milieu of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Susan Squier's anatomy of the embryo in modern literature outlines another mode of knowing--what are the means whereby science infects literature with truth claims, and literature infects science with the shapes of belief? The general question is how we negotiate the question of contagion in the hot zone of inquiry, be it science or literature.

    Interdisciplinarity always brings methodological controversy to the foreground. How a gestalt from one discipline comes to know the gestalt next door is a major concern of historical criticism. Transmission, how information and structures migrate or are transmitted from some discrete body or field, from one walled-in area to another, whether those walls are made of protein or concrete, will always be most important to interdisciplinary studies.

    I want especially to thank Robert Caserio, who originally convened the panel, and the Division on Late-Nineteenth- and Early-Twentieth-Century English Literature for assembling the panel and giving me the opportunity to chair it, and to present these papers.

    Jessica Burstein

    .

    3.3 129-135

    Science and Narcissism

    Christopher Herbert

    Science and Modernism:
    A Panel

    In a 1917 apologia for psychoanalysis, Freud portrays the history of science as a series of parallel revolutions, each in its own domain inflicting chastisement upon the retrograde influence of what he terms human "narcissism." The mandate of scientific thought, according to Freud, is to abolish all the fallacies that arise from anthropocentrism, from ascribing a privileged position in the natural world to human values or a human point of view. Copernican astronomy, Darwinian biology, and now psychoanalysis all give expression to this paramount motive of science, "the destruction of . . . narcissistic illusion." 1 This definition of scientific method as (in Freud's repeated term) the "wounding" of human self-love fits closely with his analysis in texts such as Civilization and Its Discontents of the cruel mutilations of libido that civilization necessarily exacts upon mankind. Given the sadistic impulse that he identifies as the crucial imperative in science, it is no wonder that he worries in this essay that many regard his own new science with "aversion and resistances." 2

    The indictment of anthropocentrism was hardly original to Freud. Around the turn of the twentieth century and in the following several decades, it was proclaimed with a frequency that seems to signal some noteworthy cultural perturbation. One writer after another identifies anthropomorphism or anthropocentrism as precisely the antithesis, the nullification, of science. "Anthropomorphism plays a considerable historic role" in the genesis of physical thinking, admits the mathematician Henri Poincaré in 1902, "but it can be the foundation of nothing of a really scientific or philosophical character." 3 In keeping with a series of late Victorian writers who identify anthropomorphism as the characteristic mode of thought of "primitive man," of the prescientific mentality, James Frazer in The Golden Bough attempts a vast evolutionary reconstruction of this deluded phase of thinking. Central to his analysis is his definition of myth as "a description of physical phenomena in imagery borrowed from human life"; science, which he calls the "golden key" to truth, by contrast, is the method that as its primary operation "strips nature of personality." 4 In his analysis of the superstitious roots of primitive anthropomorphism, Frazer means to drive a scientific stake at last into the heart of this ancient source of folly, ignorance, and cruelty.

    Not every contemporary observer was sanguine about soon eliminating the lethal contaminant of human narcissism from science. Arthur James Balfour declares in 1879 that "our idea of the external world is . . . anthropomorphic" inescapably, concluding from this that science is afflicted with an irrationalism that no amount of supposed methodological rigor can ever cure. 5 The anthropologist and philosopher Lucien Lévy-Bruhl, in his book Ethics and Moral Science of 1903, frames the same problem in only marginally less pessimistic terms, focusing now on biology. Scientific research strives to cleanse knowledge of what he calls its "specifically human character" and thus to attain "objectivity," he declares. 6 Yet so deeply ingrained is the anthropocentric principle in human thought, says Lévy-Bruhl, that even the mighty achievements of modern science have failed to annihilate it. "The struggle against anthropocentrism is far from ended," he concludes; "its strongest positions are not yet touched. It has only lost, so to speak, its outworks." 7

    The declaration of war on anthropocentrism may constitute the permanent creed or charter of true science, as all these writers take for granted, but the prominence of this theme in turn-of-the-century discourse indicates its distinct period-specific character, too, as one component of the wave of new thought and expression, and of anxiety, known as modernism. As the reaction against a period perceived as in thrall to complacent sentimentalities and self-aggrandizing systems masquerading as timeless verities, modernism in one of its aspects takes a mood of critical astringency and of a principled denial of self-gratification as the mark of rectitude in sophisticated intellectual inquiry. This is the aspect of modernism anatomized, for instance, by José Ortega y Gasset in his essay "The Dehumanization of Art." Serious modern artists, he declares, take it as their mission to create artworks from which narcissistic appeals to human sentiment have been systematically purged by means of "an explicit act of dehumanization" 8 --and, for that matter, take reactions of "aversion and resistances" from the general public as evidence of their success. Modernist discourse on science converges unmistakably at this point with modernist literary interpretation.

    However, there emerges in the same period a countercurrent to the dominant trend of argument and ideology just described: a dissident movement that opposes the definition of scientific method as a suppressing of anthropocentric fallacies and stripping nature of personality. "The subject of science is the human universe," declares the mathematician W. K. Clifford at the early date of 1872; "that is to say, everything that is, or has been, or may be related to man." 9 The proponents of the movement announced by Clifford challenge the assumption that scientific objectivity must or can rest upon what are called, in a phrase much bandied about by late Victorian controversialists, "absolute truths." They argue that scientific rationality can never free itself from "imagery borrowed from human life," and that in striving to do so, it becomes incoherent and sacrifices its claim to intellectual legitimacy. They suggest that the credo of science as the persecutor of human narcissism originates in a will to tyrannical domination. This movement of what could be called the rehumanization of knowledge is inseparable from that elaboration of the relativistic principle that constitutes one of the defining intellectual projects of the modernist period. In all the forms that this project assumes, it holds up to critical analysis the widespread, almost compulsive determination to shield from view the human image stamped ineffaceably upon all the intellectual productions of our species.

    I will not dwell on Ludwig Feuerbach here, but a full retrieval of the history of the anthropomorphic theme in modern discourse would need to assign him an important chapter. In his great polemic of 1841, The Essence of Christianity, translated into English by George Eliot in 1854, Feuerbach trains his critique upon theology, but its implications extend widely into other areas of thought as well. God properly understood, Feuerbach declares, is an idealized projection of mankind; religion, the supreme expression of human narcissism, thus originates in and symbolizes "the deification of man." 10 In the words of Feuerbach's famous motto, "the beginning, middle and end of religion is MAN" (EC, 184). For malign purposes of its own, theology misrepresents this state of affairs, falsely denying the anthropomorphic character of God and in so doing "[attaching] religion to an external object" (EC, 11). In short, Feuerbach sees theology as an agency of the same denial of anthropomorphism that Freud and others ascribe honorifically to modern science--though for Feuerbach, this denial is the very reverse of a rolling back of superstition. In dispossessing humanity of its ultimate imaginative creation, it produces as its chief effect "the disuniting of man from himself"; indeed, it "sets God before [man] as the antithesis of himself," in a relation of estrangement and hostility (EC, 33). All the fanatical obsession of Christian thinkers with the category of absolute truth, all their morbid hostility to and vindictive repression of human nature, and all the sanguinary abominations of religious history--all these things flow, according to Feuerbach, from the theological denial of the truth that the divine is constructed wholly of "imagery borrowed from human life." In The Essence of Christianity, the rejection of anthropomorphism is a purely diabolical moment.

    In this essay, I will trace Feuerbach's intellectual legacy in only a single representative text, Karl Pearson's The Grammar of Science, which first appeared in 1892, fifty-one years after The Essence of Christianity. Pearson never refers to Feuerbach, but seems to have him at least unconsciously in mind as he surveys the systematic perversion of another department of knowledge, that of modern physics. The vocabulary of the polemic has shifted, in keeping with the times. What Feuerbach calls "theology," Pearson in effect names "materialism."

    The Grammar of Science begins on a note far removed from Feuerbachian skepticism, professing what looks like an orthodox faith in scientific knowledge, particularly in the burgeoning field of physics. Legitimate science appeals strictly to the reason and disavows the imagination, Pearson declares, in a distinctly anti-Feuerbachian spirit. Scientific reasoning forms an ideal training for modern citizenship in a period of rampant controversy and uncertainty, since it depends on the principle of what he terms "self-elimination," the principled setting aside of "personal bias"--in other words, of that element of narcissism or anthropocentrism that Freud also tells us is the enemy of rational understanding. 11 Science, says Pearson here, is above all a stringent, ascetic discipline, dehumanized in exactly Ortega's sense, treading unswervingly what is called "the hard and stony path of classifying facts and reasoning upon them" (GS, 17). The theory of modern science as an engine for the systematic mortification of human narcissism could hardly find a fuller expression than in this opening movement of Pearson's treatise.

    It is with a calculated rhetorical suddenness, then, that The Grammar of Science swerves into another analytical register--flying, in fact, squarely in the face of Pearson's opening profession of faith. The human creative imagination, a few pages previously excluded from the domain of respectable science, is now identified as, after all, the source "of all great scientific discoveries" (GS, 30). And now, in place of the austere discipline of scientific analysis plodding laboriously along "the hard and stony path" of fact, science, like art, proves to be driven by the jouissance proper to the experience of beauty: "both afford material for the gratification of the aesthetic judgment" (GS, 36). Pearson does not quite assert that the beauty of a scientific theory could be a measure of its truth, as others have since, but his argument points unmistakably in this direction.

    He takes a bold step further: "The universe is largely the construction of each individual mind," he declares, and is therefore "a variable quantity," altering with each succeeding generation of scientists (GS, 15). "External objects," a phrase regularly placed within quotation marks in this book, are not self-existent entities confronting human perception; rather, in accordance with what Pearson, naming his chief principle of analysis, calls "the pure relativity of all phenomena" (GS, 394 n), they are constructions of the human faculties. By the same token, scientific "laws of nature" are manufactures of human thought, without a basis in any world of external reality. "It may seem at first sight strange to the reader," says Pearson, "that the laws of science should thus be associated with the creative imagination in man rather than with the physical world outside him" (GS, 36), but such is the case, he insists. "Law in the scientific sense is . . . essentially a product of the human mind and has no meaning apart from man. It owes its existence to the creative power of his intellect. There is more meaning in the statement that man gives laws to Nature than in its converse that Nature gives laws to man" (GS, 87).

    For Pearson, in other words, once physical science falls under the sign of a principle of "pure relativity," it becomes of necessity radically and militantly anthropocentric and, in Freud's sense, narcissistic. The human being is promoted in this text to the status of nothing less than the creator of the universe and the author of its laws: in this sense, The Grammar of Science proposes its own version of "the deification of man." Yet the so-called laws of nature that human scientists, driven by the craving for esthetic pleasure, labor to articulate are in fact not so much inventions as they are simply the principles of human cognition itself. "The logic man finds in the universe is but the reflection of his own reasoning faculty" (GS, 91), says Pearson, his metaphor of reflection here bringing the Narcissus myth distinctly to mind. Science does not imagine deities in human form within nature, but it depends on an analogous mental operation, for it imagines particles, waves, and forces behaving in accordance with human laws of logic. Pearson's doctrine, we may say, paraphrasing Feuerbach, is that "the beginning, middle, and end of science is MAN."

    The reign of the false doctrines of what Pearson calls, synonymously, "materialism" and "metaphysics" has come about in accordance with exactly the dispossessing, traumatically alienating event diagnosed by Feuerbach in the domain of religious imagination--and, in the meantime, by Marx in the field of capitalist production. The materialist philosopher of science, says Pearson, "unconsciously severs himself from the products of his own reason, projects them into phenomena, only to refind them again and wonder what reason put them there" (GS, 91); this same materialist philosopher, we are told, constructs a universe of objects related by natural laws "and then--as his habit is--forgetful of his own creative facility, has converted [them] into a dominant reality behind his perceptions and external to himself" (GS, 167). Pearson, like his mentor the physicist and philosopher Ernst Mach, claims that science has no business explaining the phenomena it studies, and so he does not attempt to explain the appearance of this syndrome of perverse misunderstanding, which shrouds scientific rationality in metaphysics, and in the process, not at all incidentally, inculcates an ethic of subjection to a so-called "dominant reality" (GS, 167). As far as his text explicitly states, scientist-philosophers fall into metaphysics simply in a fit of forgetfulness. Such a complex would be easy to interpret, however, as the necessary outcome of the ideology of science being promoted with such fervor by Freud, Poincaré, and many others at this period, to the effect that the progress of scientific knowledge can only come about by means of--in fact is identical to--the repression of the vice of human narcissism. Science in this official view is that intellectual enterprise dedicated to teaching man his subordinate place in the universe, where he is to eat his bread in humility. Abjuring human creativity, imagining perceptions as external objects, and revering "absolute truth" in science as in other domains of human life--these are simply the epistemological corollaries of this moral commandment of poverty and self-abnegation: so runs the implicit logic of Pearson's text.

    To follow out this logic is to move with Pearson's help toward understanding the anti-anthropocentric dogma of turn-of-the-century science as a residue of a cultural dynamic deeply associated with the "Victorian" moment in Europe, and as playing to some degree a dissonant, unstable role, even a regressive one, with regard to the modernist enterprise at large. A definition of science as first and foremost an agency for "the destruction of . . . narcissistic illusion" is almost too symmetrical with Feuerbach's analysis of theological authoritarianism or with, say, John Stuart Mill's assertion that the defining feature of the Victorian milieu was its domination by what he called "the engines of moral repression." 12 Feuerbach's and Mill's analyses suggest, that is to say, the heavy ideological burden of Freud's idea of science; more to the immediate point, they help to make legible the satirical idiom of Pearson's Grammar of Science. His method in much of the book centers on rigorously deconstructive studies of the categories of classical mechanics (force, mass, matter, absolute space and time, causality, the ether, and so on), showing each in turn to suffer from hopeless logical incoherence and in fact to be scientifically vacuous. If we follow the skein of implication that gradually unwinds from these exercises in The Grammar of Science, we come to view the physical world constructed by Newtonian mechanics--a preposterous world of massive bodies, mysterious forces, implacable laws of causality--as, among other things, the characteristic self-expression of a cultural and intellectual system based on the repressive rule of a caste of lawgiving authorities. And this, Pearson makes sufficiently clear, is exactly the state of affairs that his theory of science is meant to address.

    What he refers to as the "maze of metaphysics which at present obstructs the entry of physics" (GS, 221) thus signifies for Pearson not an innocent intellectual miscalculation after all, but an imprisoning structure of mystification, the function of which is to lock our critical and imaginative faculties helplessly within a system of external absolutes. Physicists' elaborately circular, illogical, self-contradicting theories of such entities as force and matter, which Pearson documents at length with reference to writings of James Maxwell, Lord Kelvin, P. G. Tait, and other eminent scientists, exemplify for him the same pernicious mode of discourse allegorized by Charles Dickens in Bleak House as the "monstrous maze" of legal mumbo jumbo (an impenetrable labyrinth of "numerous difficulties, contingencies, masterly fictions, and forms of procedure"): webs of language designed in both cases to produce a condition of stupefied acquiescence to the established order. 13 Pearson's extravagant stress on human creativity and on the doctrine of "the pure relativity of all phenomena" springs from an expressly emancipatory intention, in other words. Nor does this intention confine itself to the field of absolutist Newtonian mechanics. As Henry Adams put it in his comments on what he called Pearson's "revolutionary" book, what Pearson seeks to dismantle is nothing less than the whole order of thinking that had "created a universe the essence of which was abstract Truth; the Absolute; God!" 14 Adams understood with perfect clarity the Feuerbachian impulse that drove Pearson's critique of physics.

    The modern relativistic tradition from The Essence of Christianity onward seeks to counteract the regime of dehumanized absolutes by installing a frankly anthropocentric theory of science based on human and humane values. It inserts the principles of the inescapable mutability of knowledge, of the legitimacy of "alternative constructions of reality," 15 of human freedom and (as Einstein repeatedly put it) of the almost miraculous potency of the human creative imagination, squarely at the center of the definition of science. 16 From the point of view of this mode of "humanism," devoted as it is to the licensing of an enriched, more freely speculative pursuit of knowledge, the model of scientific rationality as the instrument of the suppression of human narcissism has no place at all.

    Christopher Herbert is Professor of English and Associate Dean for the Humanities at Northwestern University. He is author of Trollope and Comic Pleasure and Culture and Anomie: Ethnographic Imagination in the Nineteenth Century . The present essay forms a part of his current work in progress, a study of scientific and literary discourse at the turn of the century.

    3.3 137-143

    Science and Citizenship: Karl Pearson and the Ethics of Epistemology

    George Levine

    Science and Modernism:
    A Panel

    When I was a boy the New York Daily Mirror ran on its masthead the injunction from John 8:32: "Ye shall know the truth and the truth shall make ye free." I was never too young to miss the irony of that statement on a Hearst newspaper, but I felt it as an irony that didn't force me to question the ideal the masthead affirmed. I didn't, however, know then that the apostle John and William Hearst were affirming a fundamental tenet of late-nineteenth-century positivism. The great Enlightenment ideal, the commitment to knowledge and rationality as a means to progressive improvement of the human condition, found one of its last important outlets in positivism. Let me red-facedly admit that--despite a lifetime of rebuffs--I have not given up that commitment.

    Karl Pearson participated vigorously in it. In his 1892 Grammar of Science, he virtually begins, in a section called "Science and Citizenship," by asserting that the scientific "frame of mind seems to me an essential of good citizenship." 1 If this looks suspiciously like science as the opiate of the masses, it may also be taken as a good-faith commitment to the view that epistemology should be driven by human needs. Put that way, it sounds not like scientific disingenuousness but pragmatist revisionism. Surely, Pearson's explanation has some contemporary resonance: "Every modern citizen," he says, "is thrust into an appalling maze of social and educational problems." And every citizen is "called upon to form a judgment apart, if it possibly may be, from his own feelings and emotions--a judgment in what he conceives to be the interests of society at large" (GS, 10). Here an Arnoldian ideal of disinterest joins with positivist idealizing of knowledge.

    The Grammar of Science, the most important summary of scientific epistemology, method, and possibility since John Herschel's Preliminary Discourse on the Study of Natural Philosophy of 1830, embraced both the political and epistemological ideals of a new vision for science and society. "The goal of science is clear," Pearson concludes; "it is nothing short of the complete interpretation of the universe" (GS, 18).

    Against this scientific imperialism it would be easy now to succumb to the temptation to push once again the argument that scientific thought--ostensibly disinterested and objective--disguises self-interest and ideological complicity. Pearson was a propagandist for strong pre-Vienna Circle positivist theory and at the same time one of the most active and important of eugenicists. The connection makes itself. There can be no mistaking that his major scientific initiatives were ideologically driven by a passion for social reform, and a reform based on a eugenic program of racial improvement.

    I want to resist that temptation. I am interested in shaking up what may be a current critical complacency latent in the idea that all knowledge is political. Of course. And then what? In Pearson's case, for example, there is the fact of "statistics." Statistics as a scientific discipline given shape and direction by Pearson is an indispensable tool of modern life. J. B. S. Haldane once remarked that Pearson's "theory of heredity was incorrect in some fundamental respects. So was Columbus's theory of geography. He set out for China, and discovered America." 2 It is partly because of this apparently odd result--the growth of a valuable science from an obviously ideologically driven enterprise--that I want to think about the implications of his work for our own relations to knowledge and science and politics. In addition, Pearson is a particularly interesting subject because his theories raise echoes of contemporary nonpositivist epistemological enterprises, and because his politics are far more complicated--he was both socialist and feminist--than the connection with eugenics first suggests. Pearson is, then, an ideal test case for my tentative exploration of the possibility of recuperating some aspects of the positivist enterprise, including certain elements of the cognitive and something like an imagination of uncontaminated knowledge.

    I don't propose, with Pearsonian hubris, to manage such a recuperation. At best, I expect to complicate the picture: Pearson's kind of positivism opens onto possibilities that many of us have been embracing and may continue to embrace, both intellectually and politically.

    I want, then, to go over some familiar ground about the positivist epistemology that undergirded Pearson's idea of science, and to watch his progress from citizenship to epistemic skepticism, to the possibility of knowing. In doing so, I will be emphasizing aspects of his thought close to current humanist critiques. And I do so because I believe that we have tended to surrender too easily the value of some sort of rational and cognitive consensus to the politically and intellectually conservative. Positivism, certainly in the hands of Pearson, was an enterprise for human betterment. Like all such enterprises, it was therefore dangerous, but no more so perhaps than our own anti-positivistic enterprises. It's worth seeing where we connect with it and why it ended up in places that have led to its dismissal.

    Let me then recall that positivism, popularly conceived as dogmatic, realistic, and fact-oriented, shares with the Nietzsche of Pearson's own day a deep-rooted skepticism, and a perspectivist belief in the inevitable human element buried in every "fact." It is initiated as much as a theory of strong disbelief as of strong belief. "The improver of natural knowledge," Huxley famously said, "absolutely refuses to acknowledge authority as such. For him, scepticism is the highest of duties." 3 The condition of strong belief is a preliminary rejection of virtually everything one has believed. The word "positivism" itself implies something of the Cartesian enterprise--the clearing away of the debris of knowledge, all that is muddy and doubtable, not "clear and distinct," for whatever foundational certainty one might find. 4

    But Pearson sought ways to resist the instability he believed in. The movement through negations to aggressively affirmative modes of positivism is a tricky one, based on fine description of the methods of science. Not Cartesian in that he begins with a total commitment to empiricism, Pearson replays Descartes's hunt for what it might be possible and necessary to believe. He sustains at once a fundamental incredulity almost as complete as Descartes's Great Doubt, and uses it to build a confident (if stringently limited) way of knowing. Part of Pearson's program was the absolute dismissal of traditional religion and metaphysics from the sphere of knowledge; the other, "positive," part was the definition of a valid mode of knowing.

    Pearson tries to argue both that everything is in principle knowable and that anything that lies outside sense impression is unknowable. This is a particularly difficult maneuver, initiating the positivist strategy of dismissing empirically indeterminable questions as nonsense, yet allowing that maybe, yes, someday, we might know about reality. But we are too ignorant to know whether we can know it. He finds the positive modes of knowledge where we might expect, in science. "Wherever there is the slightest possibility for the human mind to know, there is a legitimate problem of science" (GS, 23). But, finally, to make science valid on his terms and sweep up any metaphysical residue, he rejects all claims that science is about reality.

    Pearson's world is familiar to those who know Nietzsche's transformation of knowledge into fiction. Kant's "thing in itself" is as much fiction to Pearson as to Nietzsche; science is a mode of interpreting rather than a representation of the real. Pearson argues that we know only our own consciousnesses, that the world is in effect a construct of our consciousness (where have we heard this before?). Strictly speaking, the scientist discovers nothing: he is an inventor. The laws of nature owe their existence to the creative power of man's intellect: "There is," says Pearson, "more meaning in the statement that man gives laws to Nature than in its converse that Nature gives law to man" (GS, 77). Pearson's kind of positivism probably provided much of the intellectual ground for the paradoxes of Oscar Wilde, who was unusually knowledgeable about science, and a close reader of the naturalists, T. H. Huxley, W. K. Clifford, and John Tyndall. 5 Here, in effect, Pearson says, as Wilde would, that nature imitates art, not vice versa.

    Pearson retreats from all large knowledge claims to one fundamental recognition--not so much a cogito as a "sentio": I experience, therefore a certain "routine of perception" (GS, 111, passim) exists. Routine of perception is Pearson's antimetaphysically chilling formula for what others might call reality, the regularity of impressions that allows the mind to invent laws of nature. Scientists simply describe accurately and economically the routine of those perceptions, through which it becomes possible to infer past and future routines of perception. Such empiricist orthodoxy threatens the very stability it seeks and entails further recuperative moves. There are no "laws of nature," only descriptions of routines of perception. This purging of reality and metaphysics leaves positivism hovering over an abyss of nonknowing. (Note that the pragmatist tradition shares intimately with this positivist one the refusal to allow for science or language as "representation," particularly as representation of some "reality" that lies outside of anyone's consciousness.) For Pearson as for the pragmatists, we are all bound by the egocentric predicament.

    "Science," Pearson argues, "is in reality a classification and analysis of the contents of the mind: and the scientific method consists in drawing just comparisons and inferences from the stored impresses of past sense impressions, and from the conceptions based on them" (GS, 49). Only by making all knowledge claims pass through the narrow funnel of individual consciousness can Pearson make the world safe from the incursions of metaphysics. He thus moves himself, as so many of his contemporaries moved, inside Pater's "thick wall . . . through which no real voice has ever pierced on its way to us, or from us to that which we can only conjecture to be without." 6

    Yet Pearson's socialism entailed the belief that all individuals are bound to and subsumed under the community; his epistemology made the same requirement, for both moral and intellectual reasons. How, then, negotiate an empiricist subjectivity that makes it impossible to get beyond the self? Pearson, like many others at the time, including Wilde, Tyndall, and even Nietzsche, adopts a strategy characteristic of strayed foundationalists, the biologistic appeal to evolution.

    Pearson replaces foundations with "normality." "The universal validity of science depends," he says, "upon the similarity of the perceptive and reasoning faculties in normal civilized men" (GS, 45); and for "a conception to have scientific validity [it] must be deducible from the perceptions of the normal human being" (GS, 50). Scientific universality "has only meaning insofar as we refer to a certain type of perceptive faculty, namely, that of a normal human being" (GS, 75).

    The Foucauldian critique waits in the wings, but I defer it to get clear how Pearson makes his epistemological maneuvers. Minds, he says, are machines, and if they don't act adequately in response to stimulation, "we say that the mind is disordered, the reason wanting, the person mad" (GS, 88-89). Normality is, then, a power of evolutionary survival. In an Erewhonian way, error becomes illness, and Pearson's epistemology reaches out beyond mind to the body that seems to house it. For the mad person, "The fitting exertion would not follow the sense impression, and any such man would have small chance of surviving among men whose perceptive and reasoning faculties were attuned" (GS, 91). Interestingly, in Wilde's notebooks there is an entry under the heading "Survival of Fittest in Thought" that reads: "Nature kills off all those who do not believe in the Uniformity of Nature and the Law of Causation." 7 Thus, with no access to other people's minds, Pearson believes he can, with the concept of normality, validate knowledge claims.

    But another epistemological step, some antimetaphysical tool for knowing, is required. The crucial instrument Pearson finds, learned of course from Francis Galton, is "correlation." Things remain unknown, but a "sequence" of impressions can be known. We will never find out what causes the impressions, never get behind the screen of consciousness, and yet what we find out will be enough to increase our chances of survival. Statistics, in effect, becomes the basis of an antimetaphysical science in that it allows the invention of laws to describe in the most economical possible way the sequences of events--woops, impressions. If I experience this, I am also likely to experience that. Such language replaces the idea of cause, a word Pearson is willing to use only in a revised sense. Probability contains the idea of "provability," as Pearson himself notes. Taking into account the underdetermination of pure empirical evidence, Pearson finds that statistics provides a convincing description of the world, that is, of the routine. The "clear and distinct" of Descartes gives way to "probability." Science moves from representation of reality to statistical correlation. "Henceforward," he wrote, "the philosophical view of the universe was to be that of a correlated system of variates, approaching but by no means reaching perfect correlation, i. e., absolute causality" (GS, 188). In The Grammar of Science the metaphysics of causality becomes the science of correlation.

    All of this is very clever. Yet, res don't lie, but liars re, and we know that Pearson measured things for which he had totally inadequate information; that he posited entities like normal mental acuity, for which he had no justification; that he rejected Mendel's results in a closed-minded and rather unscientific way. Even on the grounds of conventional science, these can be detected as errors. But note in how many different ways the idea of correlation and statistics satisfies epistemological needs. Correlation makes no absolute claims about relationship; it only registers that a relationship can be inferred. The numbers used to establish correlation are comfortably free from the personal, and the trick is only (a) to make sure you are counting the right things, (b) to make sure you are asking the right questions in the right way, and (c) to make sure that the mathematics is correct. Correlative statistics seems to provide an algorithm for action and, as William James would have seen it critically, precludes the one real necessity, the need and responsibility to choose. But James's critique does not preclude the necessity for shareable knowledge. And what I want to emphasize here is Pearson's brilliant effort to construct the shareable, rather than to insist on its adequacy.

    When I first read Pearson I didn't know of his connections with eugenics, and I followed the circuits of his argument without trying to resist. Pearson's social goals were allied to his science because he believed that true knowledge was attainable, and that once attained it would carry sufficient weight to guide political and moral action. Current strategies of the critique of science manifest similar attempts to demonstrate a set of facts (the incoherence of the narrative of ideal science, for example) in order to produce social goals. Donna Haraway, for example, imagines a science that would make "a no-nonsense commitment to faithful accounts of a 'real' world, one that can be partially shared and friendly to earth-wide projects of finite freedom, adequate material abundance, modest meaning in suffering, and limited happiness." 8 I'm not trying to equate Haraway and Pearson, but to call attention to a fundamental similarity in their projects: science tries to provide the best possible description of its subject in order to produce a social ideal. This is not the normal way philosophers and scientists themselves talk about science these days, yet the roll call of those who connect the project of science with social goals is impressive--Francis Bacon, John Herschel, Huxley, Pearson, Karl Popper, Bruno Latour, Haraway.

    The usual idea that the intrusion of social and personal ambitions into the working of science disrupts the possibility of disinterest and therefore of true knowledge might well, as in Pearson's case, have it backwards. Since there is no escaping the pressure of the subjective in the act of knowing, the moral recognition of the primary need to confirm knowledge with others and to sustain the larger community in conditions of equity and fairness could in fact lead to the sorts of disciplined restraint of the personal that could lend credibility to assertion.

    The attempt to make statistics a perfect epistemological machine that allows impersonality in a system otherwise inevitably biased was an important enterprise in its effort--perhaps excessive--to get beyond the personal, to discipline the desires, to penetrate the disguises of ideology. That Pearson developed various statistical strategies through his biometric work has not invalidated those strategies. That the ingenuities of science have been touched by the pressures of money, ambition, and social hierarchy has not diminished the importance of its modes of knowing. Pearson's epistemology, the positivist ecstasy (or effort to stand outside the self) and social critiques of science each tend to set their sights far too high. They each assume that the only way to achieve rational authority in knowledge is to distinguish radically the knower from the act of knowing, and absolutely and austerely to refuse to affirm any knowledge that lacks the authority of valid evidence, however that may be defined. This is veritably a Cartesian standard of doubt, and it exemplifies what Rom Harré has called "the fallacy of 'high redefinition.'" 9

    It is not clear to me that although beginning with several assumptions not available to Pearson--that the eugenic project is an evil one, that science has been driven in part at least by strong nonrational forces, and that it has not been an unequivocal force for good--current strategies of negotiating with skepticism and with the impossibility of ideal self-repression are clearly an improvement on Pearson's. Ironically, positivism and its enemies negotiate the same difficulties with the same end: an ideal of valid, shareable, humanly usable knowledge. The excesses of resistance to the inescapability of the partial in the projects of knowledge and good citizenship do not negate the projects. It's not that science and citizenship are oxymoronic, only that our definitions of these terms need modification in the light of ideas like Pearson's and in the light of his failures.

    Current strategies for negotiating with skepticism and with the impossibility of self-repression are not self-evidently an improvement on Pearson's. The ideal of disinterest still has work to do in our society. The ideal of modest truth claims, connected to disinterest, has yet more work to do.

    For Pearson science, broadly, was rigorous thinking that makes the minimal possible claims based on the fullest possible experience in order to improve the quality of human life. I am not arguing for this epistemology, but for a recognition of our continuing investment in his kind of epistemology, for the importance of attempting to reaffirm the possibility of human connection through rational understanding and knowledge, and our responsibility for it.

    George Levine is Kenneth Burke Professor of English at Rutgers University and Director of the Center for the Critical Analysis of Contemporary Culture. He is author of Darwin and the Novelists and, most recently, of a book of birding memoirs, Lifebirds . Currently he is at work on a study of the way scientific objectivity develops from and influences the main directions of Western narrative andWestern ethics.

    3. T. H. Huxley, Methods and Results (London: Macmillan and Co.,1893), 40. See also in the same volume, "Descartes' Discourse on Method" where, using Descartes, Huxley in effect announces the credo of the non-Comtist positivists:

    there is one guiding rule by which a man may always find this path, and keep himself from straying when he has found it. This golden rule is--give unqualified assent to no propositions but those the truth of which is so clear and distinct that they cannot be doubted. . . . The enunciation of this great first commandment of science consecrated Doubt. It removed Doubt from the seat of penance among the grievous sins to which it had long been condemned, and enthroned it in that high place among the primary duties, which is assigned to it by the scientific conscious these latter days [169].

    3.3 121-126

    Response

    Walter Benn Michaels

    Our America and Nativist Modernism:
    A Panel

    Our America has two theses, one historical and one theoretical. The historical thesis describes the emergence of a distinctly modern concept of racial identity and its transformation--already implicit and never complete--into the concept of cultural identity. The transformation is never complete because culture, imagined not as our actual beliefs and practices but as the beliefs and practices that are appropriate for us, can never free itself from race; the transformation is always implicit because race presents itself from the start as a kind of ideal, something we must not only embody but live up to. What Our America calls nativist modernism is the literature of this transformation and of the dramas of identity it makes possible: the betrayal of your culture and the recovery of your culture, the effort to become yourself and the struggle to remain yourself. Our America understands both the characteristic thematic ambitions of American modernism (e. g., for "the family" to maintain itself) and its characteristic formal ambitions (e. g., for the poem to be itself) as expressions of these identitarian commitments. The theoretical thesis is that any notion of cultural identity that goes beyond the description of our actual beliefs and practices must rely on race (or something equivalent, say, sex) in order to determine which culture is actually ours. Hence the idea of cultural identity--despite the fact that in recent years it has customarily been presented as an alternative to racial identity--is in fact, not only historically but logically, an extension of racial identity.

    Marjorie Perloff, Robert von Hallberg, and Charles Altieri focus most of their attention on the historical thesis. They argue that it is at best only partially true, which is to say, true only of a few major modernist writers and not entirely true even of them. They also think that modernism as a movement is diminished by my account of its social meaning; indeed they think that the value of literature itself is diminished by my account of modernism's social meaning. Perloff and Altieri also disagree with the theoretical thesis. Perloff defends the idea of racial/cultural identity on the social constructionist grounds that "identity is largely a question of how others perceive us" ; Altieri defends the idea of cultural heritage (racial/cultural identity in its historicist mode) on the grounds that it can function as a purely "educational" concept without a "racial basis" .

    Neither of the theoretical objections seems to me to have much force. Perloff apparently thinks that because the critique of identity "cut no ice" with the Nazis we should accept what "the history of our brutal century has taught us, identity is largely a question of how others perceive us" . But, even leaving aside the particular question of why the Nazis' commitment to the primacy of identity should count as an argument in its favor, Perloff's idealism is both theoretically incoherent (the belief that people belong to races is not in itself evidence that people belong to races) and politically disabling (what grounds would we have for criticizing the Nazis if we didn't think that their perceptions of Jewish identity were mistaken). Altieri doesn't think we can save cultural identity simply by validating everyone's mistakes and accepting Perloff's criteria (if somebody thinks you are something, then ["largely"] you are the thing they think you are); he thinks we can save it by understanding it neither as racial entitlement nor as shared beliefs but as "shareable competencies" . Thus where I argue that Shakespeare's belonging to our cultural heritage can only be a consequence of rather than a motive for our reading him (if we do, he will; if we don't, he won't), Altieri says that, "so long as we teach literature," "anyone whose interests are directed toward such materials will profit from trying Shakespeare" ; to encourage people to try Shakespeare, he thinks, is thus to encourage them "to try out identifications with a heritage even if there is no racial basis for the identification" . But how does being interested in a subject (literature) get turned into (or equated with) identifying with a heritage? No one will deny that if you're interested in literature it's useful to know something about Shakespeare, but the point of appeals to cultural heritage is not, of course, to find new words to describe peoples' cultural interests. It is to identify those things that count as part of your culture whether or not you are interested in them.

    The historical objections seem to me more serious. For if modernism, as Perloff plausibly says, "does not . . . belong to the United States alone" , any attempt to insist upon its national and even nationalist character may look dubious, 1 and so a certain proportion of these responses is devoted to reminding me that there were important modernist writers who were not American nativists. But the undeniable truth of this assertion does not in itself gainsay my claim that many American modernists were; more interestingly, it does not address the question of the relation between international modernism and the increasing prominence of racial identity as a meaningful social category in, most obviously, France and Germany, but not insignificantly in Britain, Italy, and (with allowances for the dramatic changes produced by the revolution) in Russia as well. Which is just to say that, although my respondents tend to think of the international character of modernism as counting against my insistence on the primacy of race/culture (von Hallberg says that my nativist modernism is "much more nativist than modernist" because the "connections" of my authors to international trends are "faint" [115]), the truth may be just the opposite--what may be most international about international modernism is its involvement with those categories of identity that have played such a central and often dominant role in European history throughout the twentieth century. From this standpoint, it would be precisely my authors' obsession with a racialized Americanness that would mark most clearly their participation in modernism as an international movement.

    This does not mean, of course, that international modernism should be understood as a collection of local nativisms on the American model. Modern American nativism, as I describe it, is essentially anti-imperialist, originating in the representation of the resistance to Reconstruction as the resistance to empire and deploying its pluralist racism against the very idea that people of different cultures could be ruled by the same government. Nothing could be less true of racism in England or, indeed, of the racial commitments of writers like Ezra Pound and T. S. Eliot whose literary ambitions, it is traditionally argued, were formed in London before the war. Perloff thinks "a consideration of Pound's or Eliot's nativism" would have usefully complicated my argument but my argument is that Pound and Eliot weren't nativists, and that their anti-pluralism produced racial commitments very different from (if no less racist than) those of F. Scott Fitzgerald and Ernest Hemingway. More generally, although it is true that the emergence of modernism is linked almost everywhere to the rise of race-based modes of social organization, it does not follow that these modes were everywhere the same: anti-Semitism in France, for example, was deployed in the mobilization of a mass politics; in the U. S., it tended to express a certain hostility to the very idea of mass culture (Negrophobia did the work of racializing "the people"). Marcel Proust is not Gertrude Stein, and it would be a mistake to think that what Jewishness meant to the author of The Making of Americans was the same as what it meant to the author of Du côté de chez Swann. But it would also be a mistake to think that the question of identity was irrelevant to either.

    Of course, one might still argue, as von Hallberg does, that "literary history is better justified" when "it records some deviance from social, political, and institutional history" , and thus that literary history should focus its attention on those modernists who were critical of the primacy of race/culture. He finds this critical deviance exemplified in William Carlos Williams's commitment to hybridity instead of purity, as in Père Rasles's "will 'TO MARRY . . . to hybridize, to crosspollenize' with the North American continent and its Indian inhabitants" . But, even setting aside for a moment the question of how to understand this commitment to hybridization, it should be clear that the demonstration that a writer like Williams was committed to hybridity instead of purity cannot really count against a description of modernism that insists on the absolute centrality of the categories of a racialized identity. In an important sense, it does not matter for my argument whether an individual writer prefers racial hybridity to racial purity or vice versa. What matters is that these are the relevant choices. Thus when Altieri insists that "the gulf between Faulkner and his characters requires us to postulate within modernist culture more than one attitude toward these racial matters" (108-9), he seems to me (about the "attitude" if not the "gulf") exactly right. There are indeed differences in "attitude" between modernist writers and the point of Our America is not to deny those differences; it is instead to describe the logic according to which it is precisely those differences (differences about "racial matters") that are the ones that matter. They aren't the ones that mattered to Edith Wharton or Henry James. 2

    Whether these differences amount to the deviance called for by von Hallberg is another question. Von Hallberg thinks that In the American Grain is distinguished from more "romanticized" texts by Père Rasles's will "TO MARRY" the Indians but--from Hart Crane to D. H. Lawrence to Robinson Jeffers to Zane Grey--no event in the nativist canon was more frequent than sex with an Indian. Although von Hallberg's equation of "miscegenation" with the impulse "'to hybridize'" seems plausible enough, what the fantasy of sleeping with truly native Americans seemed in fact to offer was hybridization without miscegenation, a way of legitimizing rather than problematizing one's Americanness. To see the point here, one has only to note the relative absence of romantic fantasies about crosspollenizing with Jews. Tom Outland, in The Professor's House, imagines himself descended from Indians and so imagines the Anasazi relics he has discovered as belonging to his family--the American family. Roddy Blake, by contrast, sells the relics and thus betrays his country, "like Dreyfus." 3 And Louie Marsellus marries the sister who should have married Tom, thus guaranteeing that the Professor's descendants will be Jewish, not Indian. The desire to "hybridize" with Indians was the desire to make your children as native as their native American parent and thus to make yourself--the parent of a native American--as American as your children.

    Needless to say, most of this sex was, as Altieri would say, "of a distinctly metaphoric kind" . Altieri seems to think that this is a problem, that unless these writers "based specific political decisions" on the "identifications" I describe , there is nothing political about them. 4 But it's hard to see why writing books that reimagine American history and reconstruct a national poetic along lines that articulate the principles of Calvin Coolidge (which is, if I am right, what William Carlos Williams was doing between 1923 and 1929) counts as less political than actually voting for Calvin Coolidge. It is, of course, precisely what they see as this reduction of the literary to the political that most concerns all three of my respondents; they think that it makes literature, or at least the study of literature, unnecessary: "For why do we need to study literature in order to learn about the identity politics of the 1920s?" Perloff asks, "Surely there are more informative and efficient ways than to read dozens of what are largely undistinguished novels" . Here their defense of modernism becomes the defense of the literary as such, and we are confronted with an opposition--between literature and history or "cultural studies"--that the New Criticism made foundational for the modern discipline of literary criticism (an opposition that many on the "cultural studies" side would no doubt find just as gratifying--the fact that 's respondents all take the literature side has an easy, but for the issues under discussion here, irrelevant institutional explanation). But, whatever the ultimate theoretical merit of this opposition may be, the texts discussed in Our America make immediately clear certain of its more obvious limitations. Does Faulkner's attempt to imagine the transformation of words into things belong to literature or to history? If, on the one hand, nothing is more characteristic of the literary ambition of modernism than its effort to overcome reference, its effort to make the words be the things rather than refer to them, nothing, on the other hand, is more characteristic of the social history of modernity than the emergence of the identitarian project of being yourself. Indeed, the invention of the various dramas of identity that I describe--betraying one's identity or defending it, repudiating it or recovering it--is unimaginable and probably would have been impossible without literary modernism's various idealizations of its own literariness, which is to say, of the quintessentially identitarian question of the text's relation to itself.

    Robert von Hallberg opens this discussion by saying that Our America describes American modernism as "driven by considerations of race and identity more than of form and representation" . But Our America argues that questions of race and identity are questions of form and representation, and, although the converse need not be true--although questions of form and representation need not be understood as questions of race--Our America argues that in modernism they were, that what distinguishes modernism is precisely its understanding of questions of form and representation as questions of race and identity. Maybe we should describe modernism as something like the research-and-development division of identitarianism. In any event, just as I don't think you can understand literary modernism without understanding its participation in the production of identitarianism, I don't think you can understand modern identitarianism without understanding literary modernism. The real reductionism is in thinking that you can somehow separate the two.

    Walter Benn Michaels is Professor of English and the Humanities at The Johns Hopkins University. He is currently at work on a book called History of Theory: 1966-1996.

    Notes

    I am grateful to the editors of Modernism / Modernity for arranging this exchange, and, given their fundamental disagreements with its goals and methods, I am particularly grateful to Charles Altieri, Marjorie Perloff, and Robert von Hallberg for their careful and generous consideration of Our America.

    1. But not, Perloff to the contrary notwithstanding, even"inadvertently racist" . The redescription of American national identity as American racial identity was, no doubt, the fondest dream of American nativists, but Perloff is mistaken in thinking that this dream has been fulfilled.

    2. This may be an opportune moment to point out that I don't in factthink that their indifference to or ignorance of the uses of racial identity make Wharton and James less great writers. And, although Perloff characterizes me as "an anti-aestheticist" , I agree with her that some works of art are better than others. It is, of course, a little disconcerting to be lectured on aesthetic value by someone who thinks that Charles Bernstein is a major poet, but the fact that Perloff herself can only occasionally tell the difference between a good poem and a bad one doesn't mean that she isn't right to maintain that there is a difference.

    3. Willa Cather, The Professor's House (1925; New York:Vintage Books, 1973), 243.

    4. In a similar vein, Altieri suggests that the changes I describe inthe meaning of citizenship, changes embodied in my juxtaposition of the Immigration and the Indian Citizenship Acts, cannot be understood simply by a reading of the relevant texts. Indeed, he argues that "the very effort to establish commonness on the level of what these pieces of legislation meant for people requires overlooking the economic factors that are central in establishing different experiences of citizenship" . But the question here is not only about how people experienced citizenship but about what citizenship was: was it still, in the wake of the various technologies that had been invented to reconre it, the sort of thing that could be or should be acquired? And the answer to this question does not depend on the different economic circumstances of the various groups in American society; indeed, it was a crucial aspect of nativist modernism that it substituted the question of what your nationality was for the question of what your socioeconomic status was, that it substituted race and culture for class. The "commonness" between the Johnson Act and the Citizenship Act thus has nothing to do with some presumed commonness between Indians and immigrants; it has everything to do with common commitment of congressmen and writers to imagining the desire to succeed as the desire to pass, to reimagining Clyde Griffiths's desire to have more money as Jimmie Gatz's desire to be Jay Gatsby.
